item.title: Zcash just a flash in the 2018 bitcoin pan or something real that will last to 2020?
item.description:
Pontifications

  • From Bryce "Zooko" Wilcox's interview: The man building a ‚Äòbetter Bitcoin‚Äô on why Bitcoin isn‚Äôt the cryptocurrency for mainstream use

QUOTE

As far as I‚Äôm aware, all of the enterprise solutions of blockchain so far are still in a preliminary stage. It could be that‚Äôs just because iterating such complex and high-value systems take many years of careful effort or you could say pessimistically that blockchain is failing to satisfy their needs and it will eventually be abandoned. I don‚Äôt know which it is yet. I‚Äôve been waiting for several years now to find out about the application of blockchain to enterprise use cases which gains traction and gets more and more users and makes more money.

The Zcash and JP Morgan partnership is making an enterprise blockchain technology which could be a leading candidate for the breakthrough that allows enterprises to use blockchain for real-world use cases. The JP Morgan partnership allows smart contracts, it also allows privacy which is necessary for every enterprise. (Editor‚Äôs note: JPMorgan uses a payments platform called Quorum, built on the Ethereum blockchain. Zcash‚Äôs Zero Knowledge Proof-based method adds a layer of privacy to the transactions that happen on Quorum. See more here.)

END QUOTE

  • I have no idea what will happen but hope that by 2020 we will know if blockchain is going to be used and not abandoned.

item.title: Sheila MacNeill: Not knowing how to code is a privilege for me and a reflection of a sexist-and-not-knowing-how-teach-math-properly-culture when growing up
item.description:
Pontifications

  • My tl;dr of Sheila MacNeill's Why don't I code?: Not knowing how to code is a privilege for me and a reflection of a sexist-and-not-knowing-how-teach-math-properly-culture when growing up.

QUOTE

I‚Äôm also still a bit scared of code and programming. Irrational I know ‚Äì but I might just actually break the internet üôÇ

However, Tony‚Äôs post has really made me think. My irrational fear stems back to my early educational experiences. When I was at school and personal computers were coming of age it was made very clear that programming wasn‚Äôt for the likes of me ‚Äì a girl, not great at maths, not really interested in computers.

Those biased assumptions still lurk in the recesses of my psyche. That‚Äôs why another bigger part of me does really support and believe in the need for continued support for getting young girls in particular into coding early. It‚Äôs really important to know how things work, how as Tony says, easy it is to get things done and not just let others do it for you. Of increasing importance now is being able to articulate what you think systems should do for you, to challenge how ‚Äústuff‚Äù (aka data) is stored, collected, used/abused. Knowing about programming provides another way to have informed discussions about many, many other things.

So maybe I should make the time to learn to code a bit more and not abuse my privilege of letting others do everything for me."

END QUOTE

Read the whole thing!

  • Just like it's never too late to take up running, cross-country skiing, hiking, long walks, swimming or any athletic hobby that's not super dangerous or onerous in order to explore and expand your physical self, it's never too late to take up programming in order to expand and explore your mental self.
